climate.description: Hot conditions with wind exposure and variable weather.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through rolling Nebraska farmland. 150-mile distance with moderate elevation.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Amateur division of Gravel Worlds. 150 miles is extreme but flat farmland terrain and amateur field.

biased_opinion.summary: Gravel Worlds Amateur is the amateur division of the Gravel Worlds series—a 150-mile challenge through Nebraska farmland. The Gravel Worlds name carries weight, and the organization is solid. Lincoln provides excellent access and amenities. However, it's flat farmland terrain with an amateur field, keeping it in Tier 3. The 150-mile distance is the main challenge—heat, wind, and endurance.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid 150-mile gravel challenge with Gravel Worlds organization. Worth it for the distance challenge and event quality. Not a destination race for terrain or field depth, but a legitimate ultra-distance test.

final_verdict.one_liner: 150-mile Nebraska farmland gravel challenge in Lincoln.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you want a 150-mile ultra-distance challenge with solid organization—yes, it's a legitimate test. If you want terrain variety or pro field depth—look elsewhere.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better ultra-distance events: Unbound 200, Dirty Kanza. For similar amateur events: other Gravel Worlds divisions.

logistics.food: Lincoln has full dining options. Stock nutrition for 150 miles.

history.origin_story: Amateur division of Gravel Worlds series.

course_description.character: Flat to rolling farmland gravel for 150 miles.
course_description.signature_challenge: 150-mile distance through Nebraska farmland with heat and wind.

non_negotiables.why: 150 miles requires extensive ultra-distance preparation and back-to-back long rides.
Nebraska August means serious heat exposure for 10-15 hours.
Nebraska farmland means significant wind exposure.

marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Amateur division ultra-distance challenge in Lincoln.

logistics.explanation: Sandhills Global Event Center provides a proper race headquarters with camping, packet pickup Thursday 10am-7pm, and emergency check-in race morning. Multi-day event structure with expo suggests they understand race weekend logistics. Lincoln offers reasonable access and infrastructure without big-city hassles or parking nightmares.

length.explanation: 150 miles through rural farmlands with over 10,000 feet of climbing separates serious endurance athletes from weekend warriors. The 9:59pm cutoff acknowledges this is about surviving the distance, not racing the clock. Starting at 6:30am for general field gives riders over 15 hours to complete what the organizers call an 'unparalleled challenge.' Among the longest in gravel, comparable to Badlands.

technicality.explanation: The course ventures through rural farmlands of southeastern Nebraska with constant rolling hills rather than technical features. This is Nebraska grassroots gravel focused on grinding power through rolling gravel seas, not advanced bike handling skills through rock gardens or steep technical descents. Less technical than The Mid South. As Organizer Jason Strohbehn puts it: "We're proud to be leaders in moving our sport forward. But this isn't just about the pro race."

elevation.explanation: Over 10,000 feet of climbing across 150 miles comes from constant rolling hills that accumulate gradually. The GW300 description emphasizes how Nebraska terrain builds elevation through persistent moderate grades rather than dramatic climbs, creating death by a thousand small hills across southeastern farmland. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Late August in Nebraska means potential extreme heat conditions, evidenced by early start times and organizer warnings. The 6:30am general field start suggests awareness of heat building across exposed farmland with minimal tree cover during the 15+ hour event window. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Lincoln, Nebraska sits around 1,200 feet above sea level with no meaningful altitude training effect. The constant rolling hills provide elevation gain through climbing, not thin-air challenges from starting elevation. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Exploring 150 miles through southeastern Nebraska's rural farmlands offers discovery of terrain most riders have never seen. The GW150 includes checkpoints and high-seas refueling opportunities, adding elements beyond typical organized rides while maintaining support structure.

prestige.explanation: Year 17 status and the largest single-day gravel prize purse of $150,000 for elites elevates the event profile. Winners receive the distinctive Sword Trophy and title 'Captain of the Gravel Seas' along with World Champions Jersey. Rule #1 is 'BE COOL!' which captures the grassroots-meets-serious-racing atmosphere.

race_quality.explanation: The $150,000 prize purse distributed evenly across men's and women's fields brings professional competition to Nebraska farmland. Organizer Jason Strohbehn emphasizes using the pro field to increase safety, expand resources, and elevate the experience for everyday riders through improved course support.

experience.explanation: The full week format includes Tuesday MTB races, Wednesday-Thursday expo, Friday triathlon nationals, and Saturday's main gravel events. Jason Strohbehn's focus on making Gravel Worlds better for everyday riders through expanded expo and on-course resources shows investment beyond just the championship distance.

community.explanation: Rule #1 'BE COOL!' sets the tone for what organizers call a week of 'competition, camaraderie, and collective fun.' The event includes multiple distances from 35 to 300 miles, free junior entry, and connects to Nebraska DEVO youth programs with 200+ kids and 80 coaches.

field_depth.explanation: The amateur field rides behind elite pro starters in the general field category starting at 6:30am. While the pro field draws serious talent with the massive prize purse, the age group categories receive jerseys but Nebraska location limits the depth of amateur competition. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As Organizer Jason Strohbehn puts it: "We're proud to be leaders in moving our sport forward. But this isn't just about the pro race."

value.explanation: Jason Strohbehn's commitment to improving the everyday rider experience through expanded expo, increased safety, and more on-course resources suggests value beyond just the distance challenge. Free junior entry and discounted U23 pricing show investment in accessibility.

expenses.explanation: Lincoln, Nebraska location keeps lodging and food costs reasonable compared to destination races. Camping available at Sandhills Global Event Center provides budget option. Related run events show $140 pricing structure, suggesting entry fees won't require major budget planning. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
